title: August 2011 Licensure Exam: Paper Four
description: Examination covering Mental Health, Community Health, Management, and Teaching methodology.

questions.question: The behaviour expected of a person occupying a position is called:
questions.explanation: A 'role' is the set of norms, behaviors, and expectations attached to a specific position or status in society. 'Status' is the position itself.
questions.hint: Think of the 'part' an actor plays.

questions.question: The Cognitive domain of learning is concerned with:
questions.explanation: Bloom's Taxonomy divides learning into Cognitive (mental skills/knowledge), Affective (feelings), and Psychomotor (physical skills). Option D lists only cognitive elements.
questions.hint: Cognitive relates to the brain, thinking, and knowing.

questions.question: The learned social heritage passed from one generation to another is called:
questions.explanation: Culture is the complex whole of knowledge, belief, art, morals, etc., acquired by man as a member of society and transmitted across generations.
questions.hint: It encompasses traditions, language, and beliefs passed down.

questions.question: Intervention in schizophrenia at the family level may include:

options.text: Education about schizophrenia, improving communication, increased expressed emotions and daily contact
Expanding social networks, education on schizophrenia, improving communication
Increased expressed emotions and daily contact, reducing communication
Adjusting expectations, reducing social networks and hours of contact

questions.explanation: Family therapy aims to reduce 'Expressed Emotion' (hostility/criticism) to prevent relapse. Expanding support and education are key.
questions.hint: High Expressed Emotion (HEE) causes relapse, so we want to avoid increasing it.

questions.question: The five specific types of delusional disorders are:

options.text: Jealous, persecutory, somatic, erotomanic and grandiose
Paranoia, persecutory, sadness, grandiose and erotomanic
Persecutory, unrealistic, indifference, somatic and jealous
Indifference, somatic, jealous , erotomanic and grandiose

questions.explanation: DSM criteria define the subtypes as Erotomanic, Grandiose, Jealous, Persecutory, Somatic, and Mixed.
questions.hint: Look for the list that consists purely of recognized delusion types.

questions.question: The examination done at the end of the course is a form of:
questions.explanation: Summative evaluation assesses learning at the end of instruction (summing it up). Formative happens during instruction.
questions.hint: It 'sums' up the learning.

questions.question: Factors predicting a good prognosis for depression in old age are:

options.text: Onset before age 70, short duration, good previous adjustment, absence of physical illness
Good previous adjustment, wealth, absence of physical illness, long duration
Wealth, family support, onset before age 60, good previous adjustment
All children employed, wealth, good family support, onset before age 50

questions.explanation: Good prognosis is linked to acute onset (short duration), absence of brain changes/physical illness, and good pre-morbid adjustment.
questions.hint: Short duration and healthy physical state are positive signs.

questions.question: Psychological development that occurs in puberty includes:

options.text: Development of abstract thinking, greater independence from the family
Formation of personal and sexual identity, disregard of values

questions.explanation: Adolescence involves Piaget's formal operational stage (abstract thinking) and developing independence/identity.
questions.hint: Think about the cognitive shift to abstract thought.

questions.question: In child development, crying at 3–4 months of life communicates:
questions.explanation: By 3-4 months, cries differentiate into specific needs: primarily hunger, pain, and fatigue.
questions.hint: The basic survival needs.

questions.question: According to IMCI guidelines, the drug of choice for treatment of chronic ear infection is:

options.text: Oral Amoxillin for at least 10 days
Topical gentamicin ear drops for at least two weeks
Topical quinolone ear drops for at least two weeks

questions.explanation: Chronic Suppurative Otitis Media (CSOM) is treated with ear wicking and topical quinolone drops for 14 days.
questions.hint: Topical treatment is preferred for chronic discharge.

questions.question: Factors that contribute to neonatal jaundice include:

options.text: Reduced liver perfusion, increased uptake of bilirubin
Enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin, shortened RBC life span
Increased uptake of bilirubin, increased liver perfusion

questions.explanation: Neonatal jaundice is caused by high RBC turnover (short life), immature liver conjugation, and increased reabsorption from the gut (enterohepatic circulation).
questions.hint: Think about why bilirubin accumulates in newborns.

questions.question: Principles of management of respiratory distress in children include:

options.text: No feed by mouth, nasogastric tube aspiration, antibiotics
Nasogastric tube aspiration, chest exercises, intravenous fluids
No feed by mouth, intravenous fluids, tracheostomy care

questions.explanation: Severe distress requires NPO (to prevent aspiration), NG decompression, and antibiotics (common cause is pneumonia).
questions.hint: Feeding is unsafe when breathing is very fast.

questions.question: A hypothesis is a statement that:

options.text: Maintains reliability and validity in research
Proposes a relationship between two variables
Explains relationships between descriptive and cross sectional research

questions.explanation: A hypothesis is a tentative prediction about the relationship between two or more variables.
questions.hint: It predicts how X relates to Y.

questions.question: The purpose in a research study should be:

options.text: Clear, unambiguous and state the target population
Declarative, ambiguous and state relationships among the variables
Clear and open, not stating relationships among the variables
Ambiguous, state target population, consider confidentiality

questions.explanation: A purpose statement must be precise (unambiguous) and identify the specific population and goals.
questions.hint: Ambiguity is never a goal in research.

questions.question: A sampling technique in which units are selected on the basis of availability is known as:
questions.explanation: Convenience sampling selects participants who are readily available.
questions.hint: It is 'convenient' for the researcher.

questions.question: Evaluation of students’ learning aims to:

options.text: Ascertain their current level of knowledge
Find out if there are slow learners
Make judgment on the classroom arrangement
Ensure all the students attend to classroom activities

questions.explanation: Evaluation measures the achievement of learning objectives (knowledge/competence).
questions.hint: To see what they have learned.

questions.question: Work related stress may emanate directly from:

options.text: Lack of support from co-workers, religious differences
Religious differences, distance to work station

questions.explanation: Direct work stressors include role ambiguity (not knowing duties) and role overload (long hours).
questions.hint: Look for factors strictly related to the job itself.

questions.question: The technique in which reinforcements or punishments are used to influence behaviour is:
questions.explanation: Operant conditioning (Skinner) uses consequences (reinforcement/punishment) to modify behavior.
questions.hint: It 'operates' on the environment to produce consequences.

questions.question: Drowning is defined as:

options.text: Form of asphyxia in which access of air to the lungs is prevented
Accidental submersion of the body in water
Intentional submersion of the body in water
Form of asphyxia where access of air OUT of lungs is prevented

questions.explanation: It involves respiratory impairment (asphyxia) from submersion preventing air entry.
questions.hint: Focus on the physiological mechanism (lack of air).

questions.question: A variable is:

options.text: An individual selected to represent a study population
A measurable characteristic that assumes different values among the subjects
An individual in the population willing to participate
A measurable characteristic which is independent

questions.explanation: A variable is a characteristic that can vary (change value) across subjects.
questions.hint: It 'varies'.

questions.question: Select five methods of probability sampling.
questions.explanation: Probability sampling involves random selection where every unit has a known chance of selection.
questions.hint: Methods that involve randomization.

questions.question: Which of the following are structures of the digestive system that should be labeled on a diagram?
questions.explanation: Major digestive organs include the alimentary canal and accessory organs. The trachea is respiratory.
questions.hint: Select organs involved in digestion.

questions.question: Arrange the 5 stages of normal grief (Kubler Ross) in order:
questions.explanation: DABDA: Denial, Anger, Bargaining, Depression, Acceptance.
questions.hint: Remember the acronym DABDA.

questions.question: Order Freud's psychosexual stages of development chronologically:
questions.explanation: Oral -> Anal -> Phallic -> Latency -> Genital.
questions.hint: Starts with the mouth (Oral) and ends with maturity (Genital).

questions.question: What are the advantages of student-centered learning?
questions.explanation: Student-centered learning is active, engaging, and promotes independence.
questions.hint: Focus on benefits to the learner's engagement.

questions.question: Which items are required when citing a research article?
questions.explanation: Standard citation includes Author, Year, Title, Journal, Volume, Issue, Pages.
questions.hint: Information needed to find the exact article.

questions.question: Select the objectives of the Mental Health Act 1989.

options.text: Provide for care and rehabilitation of mentally ill
Protect rights and welfare of patients

questions.explanation: The Act aims to regulate care, protect rights, manage property, and ensure safety.
questions.hint: It regulates care and protects rights.

questions.question: Identify the essential components of a Lesson Plan.
questions.explanation: A lesson plan must include administrative details, objectives, content, methodology (activities), resources, and evaluation.
questions.hint: The blueprint for a teaching session.

questions.question: Case Study: Mr. X (Drug Induced Psychosis). Select the correct definition and CAGE questions.

richContent.content: Context: Substance abuse assessment using CAGE.

options.text: Definition: Maladaptive pattern leading to impairment/distress

questions.explanation: CAGE: Cut down, Annoyed, Guilty, Eye-opener.
questions.hint: Recall the CAGE acronym.

questions.question: Case Study: Mini (5yo) with Status Asthmaticus. Select correct Pathophysiology and Management.

richContent.content:
Patient: Mini, 5 years old.

Diagnosis: Status Asthmaticus.

options.text: Pathophysiology: Mucus plugging and Air Trapping
Pathophysiology: Alveolar collapse due to lack of surfactant

questions.explanation: Status Asthmaticus involves severe bronchospasm, edema, and mucus. Management is aggressive: Oxygen, SABA, Ipratropium, Steroids, Magnesium.
questions.hint: Severe asthma unresponsive to initial treatment.
